elements.content: As part of our studies of ligands containing an electron-deficient [3]-radialene core we discovered that the hexadentate ligand hexa(4-cyanophenyl)[3]-radialene 1 forms 6,3-connected 2-D coordination polymers on reaction with silver(I). Compounds {[Ag(1)](PF6)·2(CH3NO2)} n 2 and {[Ag(1)](ClO4)·2(CH3NO2)} n 3, which are the first coordination polymers of 1, readily crystallize from solutions of the silver salt and 1 in noncoordinating nitromethane solvent and were characterized by X-ray crystallography. In these structures the ligand is hypodentate, coordinating only through four nitrile N-donors to act as a 3-connecting center. The distorted tetrahedral silver also acts as a 3-connecting center. In the extended structure the anions lie in pockets above and below the [3]-radialene core of the ligands, forming moderate and weak hydrogen bonds with four different molecules of 1. The anions are in close proximity to the electron-deficient [3]-radialene core of 1, forming weak anion−π interactions.
elements.clean_text: As part of our studies of ligands containing an electron-deficient [3]-radialene core we discovered that the hexadentate ligand hexa(4-cyanophenyl)[3]-radialene 1 forms 6,3-connected 2-D coordination polymers on reaction with silver(I). Compounds {[Ag(1)](PF6)⋅2(CH3NO2)} n  2 and {[Ag(1)](ClO4)⋅2(CH3NO2)} n  3, which are the first coordination polymers of 1, readily crystallize from solutions of the silver salt and 1 in noncoordinating nitromethane solvent and were characterized by X-ray crystallography. In these structures the ligand is hypodentate, coordinating only through four nitrile N-donors to act as a 3-connecting center. The distorted tetrahedral silver also acts as a 3-connecting center. In the extended structure the anions lie in pockets above and below the [3]-radialene core of the ligands, forming moderate and weak hydrogen bonds with four different molecules of 1. The anions are in close proximity to the electron-deficient [3]-radialene core of 1, forming weak anion-π interactions.

elements.content: We report the first coordination polymer formed with the ligand hexa(4-cyanophenyl)[3]-radialene. In the structures of {[Ag(1)](PF6)·2(CH3NO2)} n 2 and {[Ag(1)](ClO4)·2(CH3NO2)} n 3 the ligand is hypodentate, coordinating only through four nitrile N-donors to act as a 3-connecting center. The distorted tetrahedral silver also acts as 3-connecting center to give 6,3-connected 2-D coordination polymers which show anion−π interactions involving the [3]-radialene core.
elements.clean_text: We report the first coordination polymer formed with the ligand hexa(4-cyanophenyl)[3]-radialene. In the structures of {[Ag(1)](PF6)⋅2(CH3NO2)} n  2 and {[Ag(1)](ClO4)⋅2(CH3NO2)} n  3 the ligand is hypodentate, coordinating only through four nitrile N-donors to act as a 3-connecting center. The distorted tetrahedral silver also acts as 3-connecting center to give 6,3-connected 2-D coordination polymers which show anion-π interactions involving the [3]-radialene core.

elements.content: Research in the field of anion coordination chemistry has rapidly progressed over the past decade. This birth of anion coordination chemistry has originated due to the ubiquitous occurrence of anions and also the significant impact anions have in areas ranging from the environment to biology. Approaches to selectively complex anions using noncovalent interactions have been described for a large range of anions. Receptors based on different supramolecular interactions include using organic hosts with diverse hydrogen bonding donor groups, Lewis acid moieties, and electrostatic interactions with cations. More recently, metallo-supramolecular assemblies and coordination polymers have been actively targeted in this context.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Research in the field of anion coordination chemistry has rapidly progressed over the past decade. This birth of anion coordination chemistry has originated due to the ubiquitous occurrence of anions and also the significant impact anions have in areas ranging from the environment to biology. Approaches to selectively complex anions using noncovalent interactions have been described for a large range of anions. Receptors based on different supramolecular interactions include using organic hosts with diverse hydrogen bonding donor groups, Lewis acid moieties, and electrostatic interactions with cations. More recently, metallo-supramolecular assemblies and coordination polymers have been actively targeted in this context.

elements.content: Recently, anion−π interactions have attracted a significant level of attention with several reviews in this burgeoning area having been published. Some of this interest has been fueled by observations of short anion−π distances in the solid state, particularly, for example, involving derivatives of the π-electron deficient compound 1,3,5-triazine. Significant data now exist for anion−π interactions in the solid state involving phenyl and six-membered heterocyclic compounds. Anion−π interactions have also been noted in solution, originally by Schnieder, but separate studies by Kochi et al. and Johnson et al., who developed an anion receptor with an electron deficient pentafluorophenyl group, brought the significance of anion−π interactions in solution to the fore.
elements.clean_text: Recently, anion-π interactions have attracted a significant level of attention with several reviews in this burgeoning area having been published. Some of this interest has been fueled by observations of short anion-π distances in the solid state, particularly, for example, involving derivatives of the π-electron deficient compound 1,3,5-triazine. Significant data now exist for anion-π interactions in the solid state involving phenyl and six-membered heterocyclic compounds. Anion-π interactions have also been noted in solution, originally by Schnieder, but separate studies by Kochi et al. and Johnson et al., who developed an anion receptor with an electron deficient pentafluorophenyl group, brought the significance of anion-π interactions in solution to the fore.

elements.content: The class of compounds called radialenes are cyclic molecules which have the general formula of C2n H2n (Figure ). These compounds contain n ring atoms and n exocyclic double bonds, and possess a cross-conjugated π-system. Thus, the [3]-radialenes are composed of a cyclopropane core with three exocyclic double bonds, one per ring carbon (Figure a). Significantly, the hexaaryl[3]-radialenes (Figure b) are electron deficient, undergoing two reversible reductions to generate the radical anion and the dianion, respectively. Hexaaryl- and hexapyridyl[3]-radialenes can be prepared by Fukunaga’s method whereby an active methylene compound is reacted with tetrachlorocyclopropene to give the dianion, which is then oxidized to give the neutral radialene.
elements.clean_text: The class of compounds called radialenes are cyclic molecules which have the general formula of C2n H2n  (Figure ). These compounds contain n ring atoms and n exocyclic double bonds, and possess a cross-conjugated π-system. Thus, the [3]-radialenes are composed of a cyclopropane core with three exocyclic double bonds, one per ring carbon (Figure a). Significantly, the hexaaryl[3]-radialenes (Figure b) are electron deficient, undergoing two reversible reductions to generate the radical anion and the dianion, respectively. Hexaaryl- and hexapyridyl[3]-radialenes can be prepared by Fukunaga's method whereby an active methylene compound is reacted with tetrachlorocyclopropene to give the dianion, which is then oxidized to give the neutral radialene.

elements.content: The structures of (a) the parent [3]-, [4]-, [5]-, and [6]-radialenes, (b) hexaaryl[3]-radialene, (c) hexa(2-pyridyl)[3]-radialene and (d) hexa(4-cyanophenyl)[3]-radialene 1.
elements.clean_text: 1  The structures of (a) the parent [3]-, [4]-, [5]-, and [6]-radialenes, (b) hexaaryl[3]-radialene, (c) hexa(2-pyridyl)[3]-radialene and (d) hexa(4-cyanophenyl)[3]-radialene 1.

elements.content: The synthesis of hexa(4-cyanophenyl)[3]-radialene 1 has been reported previously by Oda et al., but there are no previous reports of the coordination chemistry with this potentially hexadentate ligand. Two particular characteristics initially attracted us to utilize ligand 1 for our investigations: first, the divergent nature of the donor arrangement, which should result in the formation of coordination polymers, and second, the electron withdrawing effect of the six cyano groups, which make this one of the most electron deficient hexaaryl[3]-radialene compounds reported thus far. These features prompted our investigation into the coordination chemistry of 1 and its interactions with anions in the solid state. Herein, we report two isomorphous 2-D coordination polymers formed from 1 and silver salts, and discuss anion interactions with the [3]-radialene scaffold of the ligand in the solid state.
elements.clean_text: The synthesis of hexa(4-cyanophenyl)[3]-radialene 1 has been reported previously by Oda et al., but there are no previous reports of the coordination chemistry with this potentially hexadentate ligand. Two particular characteristics initially attracted us to utilize ligand 1 for our investigations: first, the divergent nature of the donor arrangement, which should result in the formation of coordination polymers, and second, the electron withdrawing effect of the six cyano groups, which make this one of the most electron deficient hexaaryl[3]-radialene compounds reported thus far. These features prompted our investigation into the coordination chemistry of 1 and its interactions with anions in the solid state. Herein, we report two isomorphous 2-D coordination polymers formed from 1 and silver salts, and discuss anion interactions with the [3]-radialene scaffold of the ligand in the solid state.

elements.content: Melting points were recorded on an Electrothermal melting point apparatus. Infrared spectra were collected on a Perkin-Elmer BX FTIR spectrometer as KBr disks. The Campbell microanalytical laboratory at the University of Otago performed elemental analyses. Unless otherwise stated, reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used as received. Solvents were dried using literature procedures and were freshly distilled as required. 4,4′-Dicyanodiphenylmethane was prepared from 4,4′-diiododiphenylmethane by adaptation of a literature method as detailed in the , and hexa(4-cyanophenyl)[3]-radialene was prepared by a literature method.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Experimental

Melting points were recorded on an Electrothermal melting point apparatus. Infrared spectra were collected on a Perkin-Elmer BX FTIR spectrometer as KBr disks. The Campbell microanalytical laboratory at the University of Otago performed elemental analyses. Unless otherwise stated, reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used as received. Solvents were dried using literature procedures and were freshly distilled as required. 4,4'-Dicyanodiphenylmethane was prepared from 4,4'-diiododiphenylmethane by adaptation of a literature method as detailed in the , and hexa(4-cyanophenyl)[3]-radialene was prepared by a literature method.

elements.content: A solution of 1 (5.0 mg, 0.007 mmol) in nitromethane (2 mL) was combined in a vial with a solution of silver hexafluorophosphate (1.9 mg, 0.007 mmol) in nitromethane (0.5 mL). Slow evaporation of the solvent led to precipitation of 2 as bright red, diamond-shaped crystals that were suitable for X-ray crystallography (7.7 mg, 99%). Analysis calcd for C50H30N8O4F6PAg C 56.67, H 2.86, N 10.58; found C 56.66, H 2.77, N 10.30; νmax/cm−1 2227 (CN str., vs), 840 (P−F str., vs, b), 555 (P−F str., s). Carrying out the reaction with a 1:AgPF6 ratio in the range from 1:1 to 1:3 gave the same product.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Coordination Polymers. {[Ag(1)](PF6)⋅2(CH3NO2)} n  2

A solution of 1 (5.0 mg, 0.007 mmol) in nitromethane (2 mL) was combined in a vial with a solution of silver hexafluorophosphate (1.9 mg, 0.007 mmol) in nitromethane (0.5 mL). Slow evaporation of the solvent led to precipitation of 2 as bright red, diamond-shaped crystals that were suitable for X-ray crystallography (7.7 mg, 99%). Analysis calcd for C50H30N8O4F6PAg C 56.67, H 2.86, N 10.58; found C 56.66, H 2.77, N 10.30; νmax/cm-1 2227 (CN str., vs), 840 (P-F str., vs, b), 555 (P-F str., s). Carrying out the reaction with a 1:AgPF6 ratio in the range from 1:1 to 1:3 gave the same product.

elements.content: Compound 1 (5.0 mg, 0.007 mmol) dissolved in nitromethane (2 mL) was placed in a vial with a solution of silver perchlorate (1.5 mg, 0.007 mmol) in nitromethane (0.5 mL). Slow evaporation of the solvent gave 3 as bright red, diamond-shaped crystals (7.4 mg, 97%). Analysis calcd for C50H30N8O8ClAg·11/2H2O C 57.67, H 3.20, N 10.76; found C 57.54, H 2.88, N 10.31%; νmax/cm−1 2227 (CN str., vs), 1090 (Cl−O str., vs, b), 623 (Cl−O bend, m). Carrying out the reaction with 1:AgClO4 ratios between 1:1 and 1:3 gave the same product.
elements.clean_text:
{[Ag(1)](ClO4)⋅2(CH3NO2)} n  3

Compound 1 (5.0 mg, 0.007 mmol) dissolved in nitromethane (2 mL) was placed in a vial with a solution of silver perchlorate (1.5 mg, 0.007 mmol) in nitromethane (0.5 mL). Slow evaporation of the solvent gave 3 as bright red, diamond-shaped crystals (7.4 mg, 97%). Analysis calcd for C50H30N8O8ClAg⋅11/2H2O C 57.67, H 3.20, N 10.76; found C 57.54, H 2.88, N 10.31%; νmax/cm-1 2227 (CN str., vs), 1090 (Cl-O str., vs, b), 623 (Cl-O bend, m). Carrying out the reaction with 1:AgClO4 ratios between 1:1 and 1:3 gave the same product.

elements.content: Crystals were mounted under oil on a plastic loop and X-ray diffraction data collected with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using a Bruker-AXS single crystal diffraction system fitted with an Apex II CCD detector. Data sets were corrected for absorption using a multiscan method, and structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 by SHELXL-97, interfaced through the program X-Seed. In general, all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and hydrogen atoms were included as invariants at geometrically estimated positions, unless specified otherwise in additional details below. Details of data collections and structure refinements are given below. CCDC-718541 and CCDC-718542 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Crystals were mounted under oil on a plastic loop and X-ray diffraction data collected with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using a Bruker-AXS single crystal diffraction system fitted with an Apex II CCD detector. Data sets were corrected for absorption using a multiscan method, and structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 by SHELXL-97, interfaced through the program X-Seed. In general, all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and hydrogen atoms were included as invariants at geometrically estimated positions, unless specified otherwise in additional details below. Details of data collections and structure refinements are given below. CCDC-718541 and CCDC-718542 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

elements.content: Compound 1 was prepared by a literature procedure. It was found that the preparation of a starting material required for the synthesis of 1, 4,4′-dicyanodiphenylmethane (dcpm) could be improved by utilizing 4,4′-diiododiphenylmethane in place of the dichloro equivalent. This gave dcpm in an excellent 95% isolated yield after optimization. Combining nitromethane solutions of 1 and either silver(I) perchlorate or silver(I) hexafluorophosphate in stoichiometries ranging from 1:1 to 1:3, followed by slow evaporation, repeatedly yielded two isostructural 2-D coordination polymers. The two compounds {[Ag(1)](PF6)·2(CH3NO2)} n 2 and {[Ag(1)](ClO4)·2(CH3NO2)} n 3 were characterized by combustion analysis, IR spectroscopy and X-ray crystallography. Characteristic infrared stretches for the incorporated anions and subtle changes in the CN, C−H, and CC stretches for the radialene ligand were observed for both 2 and 3.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Compound 1 was prepared by a literature procedure. It was found that the preparation of a starting material required for the synthesis of 1, 4,4'-dicyanodiphenylmethane (dcpm) could be improved by utilizing 4,4'-diiododiphenylmethane in place of the dichloro equivalent. This gave dcpm in an excellent 95% isolated yield after optimization. Combining nitromethane solutions of 1 and either silver(I) perchlorate or silver(I) hexafluorophosphate in stoichiometries ranging from 1:1 to 1:3, followed by slow evaporation, repeatedly yielded two isostructural 2-D coordination polymers. The two compounds {[Ag(1)](PF6)⋅2(CH3NO2)} n  2 and {[Ag(1)](ClO4)⋅2(CH3NO2)} n  3 were characterized by combustion analysis, IR spectroscopy and X-ray crystallography. Characteristic infrared stretches for the incorporated anions and subtle changes in the CN, C-H, and CC stretches for the radialene ligand were observed for both 2 and 3.

elements.content: Bright red, diamond-shaped crystals of both {[Ag(1)](PF6)·2(CH3NO2)} n 2 and {[Ag(1)](ClO4)·2(CH3NO2)} n 3 obtained from crystallizations carried out in a 1:1 M:L ratio were found to be most suitable for X-ray crystallography, although the unit cell dimensions were also measured for crystals selected from samples formed from other starting stoichiometries. The structures of complexes 2 and 3 are 6,3-connected 2-D coordination polymers (Figure ). Both coordination polymers crystallize in the triclinic space group P1̅, with an asymmetric unit that contains one molecule of the ligand, one silver atom, one anion and two nitromethane solvate molecules. The structures were refined with some disorder problems of the silver atom (disordered over two positions, with ca. 9:1 occupancies in both structures), the perchlorate anion in compound 3 and one of the nitromethane solvate molecule in both compounds. The crystal structures are isomorphous and the cationic coordination polymer units of the two structures are isostructural.
elements.clean_text: Bright red, diamond-shaped crystals of both {[Ag(1)](PF6)⋅2(CH3NO2)} n  2 and {[Ag(1)](ClO4)⋅2(CH3NO2)} n  3 obtained from crystallizations carried out in a 1:1 M:L ratio were found to be most suitable for X-ray crystallography, although the unit cell dimensions were also measured for crystals selected from samples formed from other starting stoichiometries. The structures of complexes 2 and 3 are 6,3-connected 2-D coordination polymers (Figure ). Both coordination polymers crystallize in the triclinic space group P1̅, with an asymmetric unit that contains one molecule of the ligand, one silver atom, one anion and two nitromethane solvate molecules. The structures were refined with some disorder problems of the silver atom (disordered over two positions, with ca. 9:1 occupancies in both structures), the perchlorate anion in compound 3 and one of the nitromethane solvate molecule in both compounds. The crystal structures are isomorphous and the cationic coordination polymer units of the two structures are isostructural.

elements.content: A perspective view of the cationic 6,3-connected 2-D coordination polymer network from the crystal structures of compounds 2 and 3 viewed down the a axis of the unit cell. For clarity, the disorder of the silver(I) atom is not shown. Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (deg): 2, Ag1 N17 2.231(4), Ag1 N57 2.273(4), Ag1 N37 2.330(4), Ag1 N27 2.393(5), N17 Ag1 N57 117.80(14), N17 Ag1 N37 102.04(15), N57 Ag1 N37 129.99(15), N17 Ag1 N27 130.28(16), N57 Ag1 N27 88.29(15), N37 Ag1 N27 87.85(15); 3, Ag1 N57 2.247(3), Ag1 N17 2.247(3), Ag1 N37 2.268(3), Ag1 N27 2.403(5), N57 Ag1 N17 123.08(13), N57 Ag1 N37 129.46(16), N17 Ag1 N37 98.57(13), N57 Ag1 N27 85.52(15), N17 Ag1 N27 126.4(2), N37 Ag1 N27 91.88(15).
elements.clean_text: 2  A perspective view of the cationic 6,3-connected 2-D coordination polymer network from the crystal structures of compounds 2 and 3 viewed down the a axis of the unit cell. For clarity, the disorder of the silver(I) atom is not shown. Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (deg): 2, Ag1 N17 2.231(4), Ag1 N57 2.273(4), Ag1 N37 2.330(4), Ag1 N27 2.393(5), N17 Ag1 N57 117.80(14), N17 Ag1 N37 102.04(15), N57 Ag1 N37 129.99(15), N17 Ag1 N27 130.28(16), N57 Ag1 N27 88.29(15), N37 Ag1 N27 87.85(15); 3, Ag1 N57 2.247(3), Ag1 N17 2.247(3), Ag1 N37 2.268(3), Ag1 N27 2.403(5), N57 Ag1 N17 123.08(13), N57 Ag1 N37 129.46(16), N17 Ag1 N37 98.57(13), N57 Ag1 N27 85.52(15), N17 Ag1 N27 126.4(2), N37 Ag1 N27 91.88(15).

elements.content: In both structures, the silver atom has a flattened tetrahedral coordination geometry, with bond angles in the range 85.52(15)−130.3(2)°. Houser and co-workers recently reported a four-coordinate geometry index, τ4, whereby a value of unity indicates a tetrahedral four-coordinate geometry and a value of zero a square planar geometry. The τ4 values are 0.71 and 0.74 for the silver atoms in 2 and 3, respectively. This coordination environment involves chelation of the silver atom by two nitrogen donor atoms of adjacent arms of one ligand and monodentate coordination by two nitrogen donor atoms from two neighboring ligands to connect three different ligands in total (Figure ). The coordination to the silver atom by the nitrile moieties involved in chelating the silver atom is rather unusual, with a 17-membered chelate ring being formed in which there are N−Ag−N bond angles of 87.85(15) and 91.88(15)°, and nonlinear CN−Ag bond angles between 136.7 and 139.7°. This type of coordination to silver, and other transition metals, has been observed for nitrile groups in a number of structures where the nitrile is capping or μ2-bridging. The Ag−N bond lengths in structures 2 and 3 range from 2.230(4) to 2.403(5) Å. Within both coordination polymers 1 is hypodentate; only four out of six of the ligand donor atoms are involved in the coordination of the silver cation. This is not an uncommon situation for [3]-radialene ligands, which has been noted previously for at least three other coordination compounds. The bond lengths of the radialene core are consistent with other [3]-radialenes that have been reported. The central cyclopropane ring has bond lengths in the range of 1.408(5) to 1.451(5) Å, whereas the exocyclic double bonds range from 1.323(5) to 1.362(5) Å, consistent with other [3]-radialene structures present in the literature. In this structure the torsion angles around the “arms” of the radialene in both structures average 39.2° with the ligands in a propeller conformation, which is common for hexaaryl[3]-radialenes.

Houser and co-workers recently reported a four-coordinate geometry index, τ4, whereby a value of unity indicates a tetrahedral four-coordinate geometry and a value of zero a square planar geometry. The τ4 values are 0.71 and 0.74 for the silver atoms in 2 and 3, respectively. This coordination environment involves chelation of the silver atom by two nitrogen donor atoms of adjacent arms of one ligand and monodentate coordination by two nitrogen donor atoms from two neighboring ligands to connect three different ligands in total (Figure ). The coordination to the silver atom by the nitrile moieties involved in chelating the silver atom is rather unusual, with a 17-membered chelate ring being formed in which there are N-Ag-N bond angles of 87.85(15) and 91.88(15)°, and nonlinear CN-Ag bond angles between 136.7 and 139.7°. This type of coordination to silver, and other transition metals, has been observed for nitrile groups in a number of structures where the nitrile is capping or μ2-bridging. The Ag-N bond lengths in structures 2 and 3 range from 2.230(4) to 2.403(5) Å. Within both coordination polymers 1 is hypodentate; only four out of six of the ligand donor atoms are involved in the coordination of the silver cation. This is not an uncommon situation for [3]-radialene ligands, which has been noted previously for at least three other coordination compounds. The bond lengths of the radialene core are consistent with other [3]-radialenes that have been reported. The central cyclopropane ring has bond lengths in the range of 1.408(5) to 1.451(5) Å, whereas the exocyclic double bonds range from 1.323(5) to 1.362(5) Å, consistent with other [3]-radialene structures present in the literature. In this structure the torsion angles around the "arms" of the radialene in both structures average 39.2° with the ligands in a propeller conformation, which is common for hexaaryl[3]-radialenes.

elements.content: In the extended structure, each radialene ligand coordinates to three silver cations and it takes six units, three silver cations and three ligands, to form the hexagonal ring motif of the 6,3-coordination polymer which is repeated throughout the structure (Figure ). The 6,3 connected 2-D coordination polymer is then packed in the extended crystalline lattice in discrete layers which adopt an AB repeating structure (Figure ). The first layer A, shown colored blue, is followed by layer B, shown in green, which has its [3]-radialene units in the opposite orientation, related by a center of inversion to those of A and is also offset so that its [3]-radialene units do not reside directly below those of A. The anions reside between the layers both above and below the [3]-radialene core of each ligand in the structure. It is worth noting, however, the anions are not equidistant between the equivalent layers; in structure 2, for example, one anion ([3]-radialene centroid−PF6 centroid 4.38 Å) is located closer to the radialene core of a particular ligand than the other symmetry-related anion (5.18 Å).
elements.clean_text: In the extended structure, each radialene ligand coordinates to three silver cations and it takes six units, three silver cations and three ligands, to form the hexagonal ring motif of the 6,3-coordination polymer which is repeated throughout the structure (Figure ). The 6,3 connected 2-D coordination polymer is then packed in the extended crystalline lattice in discrete layers which adopt an AB repeating structure (Figure ). The first layer A, shown colored blue, is followed by layer B, shown in green, which has its [3]-radialene units in the opposite orientation, related by a center of inversion to those of A and is also offset so that its [3]-radialene units do not reside directly below those of A. The anions reside between the layers both above and below the [3]-radialene core of each ligand in the structure. It is worth noting, however, the anions are not equidistant between the equivalent layers; in structure 2, for example, one anion ([3]-radialene centroid-PF6 centroid 4.38 Å) is located closer to the radialene core of a particular ligand than the other symmetry-related anion (5.18 Å).

elements.content: A perspective view of two layers of 2-D coordination polymer of 2 showing the packing of crystal and the location of the hexafluorophosphate anion sites in the crystal lattice. Layer A is shown blue and layer B colored green. Nitromethane solvate molecules, hydrogen atoms, and the disorder of the silver atoms have been removed for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 3  A perspective view of two layers of 2-D coordination polymer of 2 showing the packing of crystal and the location of the hexafluorophosphate anion sites in the crystal lattice. Layer A is shown blue and layer B colored green. Nitromethane solvate molecules, hydrogen atoms, and the disorder of the silver atoms have been removed for clarity.

elements.content: Coordination polymers 2 and 3 are the first metal complexes involving hexa(4-cyanophenyl)[3]-radialene to be reported. The structures of 2 and 3 bear some structural resemblance to a 3-D coordination polymer reported by Oda et al. which is composed of hexa(4-pyridyl)[3]-radialene 4 ligands and silver metal connectors, {[Ag(4)](ClO4)·(DMSO)(MeOH)} n . In that structure the [3]-radialene acts as a tetradentate ligand with four of its six pyridyl nitrogens coordinated to four different silver atoms. In turn, each silver atom is coordinated to four pyridyl nitrogen atoms from four different [3]-radialene ligands, rather that the three ligand molecules in the structures of 2 and 3 reported here. The difference between the two types of coordination polymer may be due to the added degrees of freedom which gives hexa(4-cyanophenyl)[3]-radialene the ability to chelate to a silver atom by formation of a large chelate ring and the resulting flattened tetrahedral geometry of the silver connectors. Interestingly however, the [3]-radialene π···Oanion perchlorate interactions and phenyl C−H···Oanion hydrogen bonds in the compound reported by Oda are also similar to those in compounds 2 and 3 under discussion here and described below.
elements.clean_text: Coordination polymers 2 and 3 are the first metal complexes involving hexa(4-cyanophenyl)[3]-radialene to be reported. The structures of 2 and 3 bear some structural resemblance to a 3-D coordination polymer reported by Oda et al. which is composed of hexa(4-pyridyl)[3]-radialene 4 ligands and silver metal connectors, {[Ag(4)](ClO4)⋅(DMSO)(MeOH)} n . In that structure the [3]-radialene acts as a tetradentate ligand with four of its six pyridyl nitrogens coordinated to four different silver atoms. In turn, each silver atom is coordinated to four pyridyl nitrogen atoms from four different [3]-radialene ligands, rather that the three ligand molecules in the structures of 2 and 3 reported here. The difference between the two types of coordination polymer may be due to the added degrees of freedom which gives hexa(4-cyanophenyl)[3]-radialene the ability to chelate to a silver atom by formation of a large chelate ring and the resulting flattened tetrahedral geometry of the silver connectors. Interestingly however, the [3]-radialene π⋅⋅⋅Oanion perchlorate interactions and phenyl C-H⋅⋅⋅Oanion hydrogen bonds in the compound reported by Oda are also similar to those in compounds 2 and 3 under discussion here and described below.

elements.content: The position of the anions in structures 2 and 3 led us to examine these crystal structures in more detail. As noted (Figure ) the hexafluorophosphate anions sit almost directly on top of the [3]-radialene core in 2. The closest contact between the hexafluorophosphate anion and the ligand is through phenyl C−H···Fanion hydrogen bonding interactions, due to the propeller configuration of the [3]-radialene. The hexafluorophosphate anion forms weak hydrogen bonds with four separate ligand molecules. The 2-D coordination polymer and crystal packing generates a cavity, suitable for binding octahedral anions, from these four radialene ligands. The three fluorine atoms on one face of the hexafluorophosphate anion (Figure a) form three weak phenyl C−H···Fanion hydrogen bond interactions, with distances of 2.44, 2.81, and 2.83 Å, involving the radialene directly above the anion (layer A). The three fluorine atoms of the opposite face of the anion form two additional weak hydrogen bonds, with distances of 2.60 and 2.89 Å (layer A2) as well as two further interactions with the two radialene ligands adjacent to the anion (in layer B) with distances of 2.36 and 2.89 Å. The [3]-radialene centroid···Fanion distance is 3.47 Å, although shortest [3]-radialene π···Fanion distances involving the same ligand are 3.26 Å to an exocyclic carbon of the [3]-radialene core and 3.38 Å to a ring carbon, respectively. In complex 2 the hexafluorophosphate anion sits comfortably within the binding cavity formed by the four [3]-radialene ligands and can easily maintain the seven weak C−H···Fanion hydrogen bonds.
elements.clean_text: The position of the anions in structures 2 and 3 led us to examine these crystal structures in more detail. As noted (Figure ) the hexafluorophosphate anions sit almost directly on top of the [3]-radialene core in 2. The closest contact between the hexafluorophosphate anion and the ligand is through phenyl C-H⋅⋅⋅Fanion hydrogen bonding interactions, due to the propeller configuration of the [3]-radialene. The hexafluorophosphate anion forms weak hydrogen bonds with four separate ligand molecules. The 2-D coordination polymer and crystal packing generates a cavity, suitable for binding octahedral anions, from these four radialene ligands. The three fluorine atoms on one face of the hexafluorophosphate anion (Figure a) form three weak phenyl C-H⋅⋅⋅Fanion hydrogen bond interactions, with distances of 2.44, 2.81, and 2.83 Å, involving the radialene directly above the anion (layer A). The three fluorine atoms of the opposite face of the anion form two additional weak hydrogen bonds, with distances of 2.60 and 2.89 Å (layer A2) as well as two further interactions with the two radialene ligands adjacent to the anion (in layer B) with distances of 2.36 and 2.89 Å. The [3]-radialene centroid⋅⋅⋅Fanion distance is 3.47 Å, although shortest [3]-radialene π⋅⋅⋅Fanion distances involving the same ligand are 3.26 Å to an exocyclic carbon of the [3]-radialene core and 3.38 Å to a ring carbon, respectively. In complex 2 the hexafluorophosphate anion sits comfortably within the binding cavity formed by the four [3]-radialene ligands and can easily maintain the seven weak C-H⋅⋅⋅Fanion hydrogen bonds.

elements.content: (a) A perspective view of the packing of compound 2 showing the binding cavity in which the hexafluorophosphate anion is located. Radialene phenyl C−H···Fanion hydrogen bonds are shown as dashed lines. (b) A similar perspective view of the packing of compound 3 showing the disordered perchlorate anion in its hydrogen bonding donor pocket. Both disorder components of the perchlorate anion are shown; the chlorine atom of the dominant component is shown in yellow while the minor component is shown in cyan. Radialene phenyl C−H···Oanion hydrogen bonds are shown as dashed lines.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) A perspective view of the packing of compound 2 showing the binding cavity in which the hexafluorophosphate anion is located. Radialene phenyl C-H⋅⋅⋅Fanion hydrogen bonds are shown as dashed lines. (b) A similar perspective view of the packing of compound 3 showing the disordered perchlorate anion in its hydrogen bonding donor pocket. Both disorder components of the perchlorate anion are shown; the chlorine atom of the dominant component is shown in yellow while the minor component is shown in cyan. Radialene phenyl C-H⋅⋅⋅Oanion hydrogen bonds are shown as dashed lines.

elements.content: In structure 3, the perchlorate anion again lies almost directly over the [3]-radialene core [Figure b]. In a similar manner to 2, the four [3]-radialene ligands surrounding the anion generate a cavity which is again suitable for an octahedral anion. The tetrahedral perchlorate anion is disordered over two orientations within this cavity. The shortest contacts between the anion and the ligand are through a number of weak phenyl C−H···Oanion hydrogen bonding interactions; this is due to the phenyl protons sitting above and below the plane of the [3]-radialene and may prevent the anion from residing closer to the radialene core. The shortest hydrogen bonds involving the two sites occupied by the perchlorate anion are with the [3]-radialene ligand situated in layer A, with C−H···Oanion distances of 2.47, 2.84, and 3.08 Å. The perchlorate anion also forms hydrogen bonds with the [3]-radialene ligand situated directly below it in layer A2, with C−H···Oanion distances of 2.79 and 2.94 Å. Finally the disordered perchlorate anion interacts with two adjacent [3]-radialene ligands, which lie in the same plane as the anion itself (layer B), with C−H···Oanion hydrogen bonding distances of 2.91 and 2.98 Å, respectively. In this structure, the closest radialene centroid anion distance is 3.35 Å, which occurs between the perchlorate anion (an oxygen atom) and [3]-radialene situated in layer A. The closest radialene core π···Oanion distances to the same ligand are 3.41 Å to a ring carbon and 3.61 Å to an exocyclic carbon, respectively.
elements.clean_text: In structure 3, the perchlorate anion again lies almost directly over the [3]-radialene core [Figure b]. In a similar manner to 2, the four [3]-radialene ligands surrounding the anion generate a cavity which is again suitable for an octahedral anion. The tetrahedral perchlorate anion is disordered over two orientations within this cavity. The shortest contacts between the anion and the ligand are through a number of weak phenyl C-H⋅⋅⋅Oanion hydrogen bonding interactions; this is due to the phenyl protons sitting above and below the plane of the [3]-radialene and may prevent the anion from residing closer to the radialene core. The shortest hydrogen bonds involving the two sites occupied by the perchlorate anion are with the [3]-radialene ligand situated in layer A, with C-H⋅⋅⋅Oanion distances of 2.47, 2.84, and 3.08 Å. The perchlorate anion also forms hydrogen bonds with the [3]-radialene ligand situated directly below it in layer A2, with C-H⋅⋅⋅Oanion distances of 2.79 and 2.94 Å. Finally the disordered perchlorate anion interacts with two adjacent [3]-radialene ligands, which lie in the same plane as the anion itself (layer B), with C-H⋅⋅⋅Oanion hydrogen bonding distances of 2.91 and 2.98 Å, respectively. In this structure, the closest radialene centroid anion distance is 3.35 Å, which occurs between the perchlorate anion (an oxygen atom) and [3]-radialene situated in layer A. The closest radialene core π⋅⋅⋅Oanion distances to the same ligand are 3.41 Å to a ring carbon and 3.61 Å to an exocyclic carbon, respectively.

elements.content: A recent publication described analysis of π···anion binding interactions in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD). The mean anion−centroid distance of a perchlorate anion to a phenyl ring (a constitutional isomer of the C6H6 [3]-radialene core) was reported to be 3.29 Å and of a hexafluorophosphate anion to a phenyl ring was 3.26 Å. The authors also reported that the sum of the van der Waals radii of the interacting atoms also provided further insight into the significance of the anion−π interactions in a particular structure. For carbon and oxygen, the sum of the van der Waals radii is 3.25 Å, while for carbon and fluorine the sum of the van der Waals radii is 3.22 Å. The anion−centroid distances reported here for 2 and 3 are slightly longer than those summarized for benzene rings by Gamez et al.; as described above, the fluoride to [3]-radialene centroid distance in 2 is 3.47 Å, while the closest radialene centroid anion distance for 3 is 3.35 Å. However, it is worth noting, the [3]-radialene is a cross-conjugated π-system; the π-orbitals are localized in the exocyclic double bonds and not extensively delocalized over the central cyclopropane ring of the [3]-radialene. For instance, the hexafluorophosphate anion in 2 makes a shorter contact with the exocyclic carbon of the [3]-radialene (3.26 Å). Like previous observations of anion−π interactions in other systems, the anion−π interactions noted here are also accompanied by hydrogen bonding interactions involving acidic hydrogen atoms of the electron deficient organic compound.
elements.clean_text: A recent publication described analysis of π⋅⋅⋅anion binding interactions in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD). The mean anion-centroid distance of a perchlorate anion to a phenyl ring (a constitutional isomer of the C6H6 [3]-radialene core) was reported to be 3.29 Å and of a hexafluorophosphate anion to a phenyl ring was 3.26 Å. The authors also reported that the sum of the van der Waals radii of the interacting atoms also provided further insight into the significance of the anion-π interactions in a particular structure. For carbon and oxygen, the sum of the van der Waals radii is 3.25 Å, while for carbon and fluorine the sum of the van der Waals radii is 3.22 Å. The anion-centroid distances reported here for 2 and 3 are slightly longer than those summarized for benzene rings by Gamez et al.; as described above, the fluoride to [3]-radialene centroid distance in 2 is 3.47 Å, while the closest radialene centroid anion distance for 3 is 3.35 Å. However, it is worth noting, the [3]-radialene is a cross-conjugated π-system; the π-orbitals are localized in the exocyclic double bonds and not extensively delocalized over the central cyclopropane ring of the [3]-radialene. For instance, the hexafluorophosphate anion in 2 makes a shorter contact with the exocyclic carbon of the [3]-radialene (3.26 Å). Like previous observations of anion-π interactions in other systems, the anion-π interactions noted here are also accompanied by hydrogen bonding interactions involving acidic hydrogen atoms of the electron deficient organic compound.

elements.content: Other [3]-radialene complexes show short anion to [3]-radialene centroid distances. The 3-D coordination polymer reported by Oda with hexa(4-pyridyl)[3]-radialene exhibits a [3]-radialene core centroid to perchlorate oxygen distance 3.25 Å. Furthermore, an M6L2 prismate (where L = hexa(2-pyridyl)[3]-radialene) has been reported with a fluoride atom encapsulated within the cage, whereby the centroid of the [3]-radialene ligands are 2.67 and 2.69 Å from the central fluoride anion. However, this short interaction is supported by coordination of the fluoride anion to three of the silver atoms which in turn are sandwiched between the two [3]-radialene ligands. These results compare to a 1-D coordination polymer of 2,4,6-(dipyridin-2-ylamino)[1,3,5]-triazine (dpyatriz) and cadmium(II) nitrate, which has a triazine centroid to nitrate oxygen distance of 3.26 Å. In other examples involving the dpyatriz ligand, discrete cationic [CuX3(dpyatriz)2] complexes (where X = Cl, Br) also show quite strong interactions with a perchlorate anion.
elements.clean_text: Other [3]-radialene complexes show short anion to [3]-radialene centroid distances. The 3-D coordination polymer reported by Oda with hexa(4-pyridyl)[3]-radialene exhibits a [3]-radialene core centroid to perchlorate oxygen distance 3.25 Å. Furthermore, an M6L2 prismate (where L = hexa(2-pyridyl)[3]-radialene) has been reported with a fluoride atom encapsulated within the cage, whereby the centroid of the [3]-radialene ligands are 2.67 and 2.69 Å from the central fluoride anion. However, this short interaction is supported by coordination of the fluoride anion to three of the silver atoms which in turn are sandwiched between the two [3]-radialene ligands. These results compare to a 1-D coordination polymer of 2,4,6-(dipyridin-2-ylamino)[1,3,5]-triazine (dpyatriz) and cadmium(II) nitrate, which has a triazine centroid to nitrate oxygen distance of 3.26 Å. In other examples involving the dpyatriz ligand, discrete cationic [CuX3(dpyatriz)2] complexes (where X = Cl, Br) also show quite strong interactions with a perchlorate anion.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have been able to isolate the first examples of coordination polymers of hexa(4-cyanophenyl)[3]-radialene by reacting 1:1 mixtures of 1 with silver(I) hexafluorophosphate or perchlorate in the noncoordinating solvent nitromethane. The structures of compounds {[Ag(1)](PF6)·2(CH3NO2)} n 2 and {[Ag(1)](ClO4)·2(CH3NO2)} n 3 are 6,3-connected 2-D coordination polymers. Like other complexes of radialene-derived ligands, 1 is hypodentate and coordinates only through four nitrile N-donors to act as a 3-connecting center in 2 and 3.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have been able to isolate the first examples of coordination polymers of hexa(4-cyanophenyl)[3]-radialene by reacting 1:1 mixtures of 1 with silver(I) hexafluorophosphate or perchlorate in the noncoordinating solvent nitromethane. The structures of compounds {[Ag(1)](PF6)⋅2(CH3NO2)} n  2 and {[Ag(1)](ClO4)⋅2(CH3NO2)} n  3 are 6,3-connected 2-D coordination polymers. Like other complexes of radialene-derived ligands, 1 is hypodentate and coordinates only through four nitrile N-donors to act as a 3-connecting center in 2 and 3.

elements.content: In the extended structures of 2 and 3 the anions lie in pockets above and below the [3]-radialene core of the ligands, forming several weak hydrogen bonds with four different molecules of 1. The anions are in close proximity to the electron-deficient [3]-radialene cores of 1, forming weak anion−π interactions. These interactions appear quite general for complexes of hexaaryl- and hexapyridyl[3]-radialenes. The distances observed for these interactions are comparable to previously observed interactions reported in the literature. Calculations to further understand the significance and generality of these interactions for hexaaryl[3]-radialenes with anions are underway. In summary, we believe the hexaaryl[3]-radialene core to be a useful scaffold for new organic anion binding compounds. Furthermore, we are also investigating hexaaryl[3]-radialenes as structural scaffolds of new ligands for the synthesis of metallo-supramolecular capsules.
elements.clean_text: In the extended structures of 2 and 3 the anions lie in pockets above and below the [3]-radialene core of the ligands, forming several weak hydrogen bonds with four different molecules of 1. The anions are in close proximity to the electron-deficient [3]-radialene cores of 1, forming weak anion-π interactions. These interactions appear quite general for complexes of hexaaryl- and hexapyridyl[3]-radialenes. The distances observed for these interactions are comparable to previously observed interactions reported in the literature. Calculations to further understand the significance and generality of these interactions for hexaaryl[3]-radialenes with anions are underway. In summary, we believe the hexaaryl[3]-radialene core to be a useful scaffold for new organic anion binding compounds. Furthermore, we are also investigating hexaaryl[3]-radialenes as structural scaffolds of new ligands for the synthesis of metallo-supramolecular capsules.

The syntheses of 4,4′-diiododiphenylmethane and 4,4′-dicyanodiphenylmethane and crystallographic data in cif format. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
A solution of 1 (5.0 mg, 0.007 mmol) in nitromethane (2 mL) was combined in a vial with a solution of silver hexafluorophosphate (1.9 mg, 0.007 mmol) in nitromethane (0.5 mL). Slow evaporation of the solvent led to precipitation of 2 as bright red, diamond-shaped crystals that were suitable for X-ray crystallography (7.7 mg, 99%). Analysis calcd for C50H30N8O4F6PAg C 56.67, H 2.86, N 10.58; found C 56.66, H 2.77, N 10.30; νmax/cm−1 2227 (CN str., vs), 840 (P−F str., vs, b), 555 (P−F str., s). Carrying out the reaction with a 1:AgPF6 ratio in the range from 1:1 to 1:3 gave the same product.

{[Ag(1)](ClO<sub>4</sub>)·2(CH<sub>3</sub>NO<sub>2</sub>)}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> 3

Compound 1 (5.0 mg, 0.007 mmol) dissolved in nitromethane (2 mL) was placed in a vial with a solution of silver perchlorate (1.5 mg, 0.007 mmol) in nitromethane (0.5 mL). Slow evaporation of the solvent gave 3 as bright red, diamond-shaped crystals (7.4 mg, 97%). Analysis calcd for C50H30N8O8ClAg·11/2H2O C 57.67, H 3.20, N 10.76; found C 57.54, H 2.88, N 10.31%; νmax/cm−1 2227 (CN str., vs), 1090 (Cl−O str., vs, b), 623 (Cl−O bend, m). Carrying out the reaction with 1:AgClO4 ratios between 1:1 and 1:3 gave the same product.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Coordination Polymers. {[Ag(1)](PF6)⋅2(CH3NO2)} n  2

A solution of 1 (5.0 mg, 0.007 mmol) in nitromethane (2 mL) was combined in a vial with a solution of silver hexafluorophosphate (1.9 mg, 0.007 mmol) in nitromethane (0.5 mL). Slow evaporation of the solvent led to precipitation of 2 as bright red, diamond-shaped crystals that were suitable for X-ray crystallography (7.7 mg, 99%). Analysis calcd for C50H30N8O4F6PAg C 56.67, H 2.86, N 10.58; found C 56.66, H 2.77, N 10.30; νmax/cm-1 2227 (CN str., vs), 840 (P-F str., vs, b), 555 (P-F str., s). Carrying out the reaction with a 1:AgPF6 ratio in the range from 1:1 to 1:3 gave the same product.

{[Ag(1)](ClO4)⋅2(CH3NO2)} n  3

Compound 1 (5.0 mg, 0.007 mmol) dissolved in nitromethane (2 mL) was placed in a vial with a solution of silver perchlorate (1.5 mg, 0.007 mmol) in nitromethane (0.5 mL). Slow evaporation of the solvent gave 3 as bright red, diamond-shaped crystals (7.4 mg, 97%). Analysis calcd for C50H30N8O8ClAg⋅11/2H2O C 57.67, H 3.20, N 10.76; found C 57.54, H 2.88, N 10.31%; νmax/cm-1 2227 (CN str., vs), 1090 (Cl-O str., vs, b), 623 (Cl-O bend, m). Carrying out the reaction with 1:AgClO4 ratios between 1:1 and 1:3 gave the same product.

cln_elements.content: A perspective view of the cationic 6,3-connected 2-D coordination polymer network from the crystal structures of compounds 2 and 3 viewed down the a axis of the unit cell. For clarity, the disorder of the silver(I) atom is not shown. Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (deg): 2, Ag1 N17 2.231(4), Ag1 N57 2.273(4), Ag1 N37 2.330(4), Ag1 N27 2.393(5), N17 Ag1 N57 117.80(14), N17 Ag1 N37 102.04(15), N57 Ag1 N37 129.99(15), N17 Ag1 N27 130.28(16), N57 Ag1 N27 88.29(15), N37 Ag1 N27 87.85(15); 3, Ag1 N57 2.247(3), Ag1 N17 2.247(3), Ag1 N37 2.268(3), Ag1 N27 2.403(5), N57 Ag1 N17 123.08(13), N57 Ag1 N37 129.46(16), N17 Ag1 N37 98.57(13), N57 Ag1 N27 85.52(15), N17 Ag1 N27 126.4(2), N37 Ag1 N27 91.88(15).
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  A perspective view of the cationic 6,3-connected 2-D coordination polymer network from the crystal structures of compounds 2 and 3 viewed down the a axis of the unit cell. For clarity, the disorder of the silver(I) atom is not shown. Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (deg): 2, Ag1 N17 2.231(4), Ag1 N57 2.273(4), Ag1 N37 2.330(4), Ag1 N27 2.393(5), N17 Ag1 N57 117.80(14), N17 Ag1 N37 102.04(15), N57 Ag1 N37 129.99(15), N17 Ag1 N27 130.28(16), N57 Ag1 N27 88.29(15), N37 Ag1 N27 87.85(15); 3, Ag1 N57 2.247(3), Ag1 N17 2.247(3), Ag1 N37 2.268(3), Ag1 N27 2.403(5), N57 Ag1 N17 123.08(13), N57 Ag1 N37 129.46(16), N17 Ag1 N37 98.57(13), N57 Ag1 N27 85.52(15), N17 Ag1 N27 126.4(2), N37 Ag1 N27 91.88(15).

cln_elements.content: A perspective view of two layers of 2-D coordination polymer of 2 showing the packing of crystal and the location of the hexafluorophosphate anion sites in the crystal lattice. Layer A is shown blue and layer B colored green. Nitromethane solvate molecules, hydrogen atoms, and the disorder of the silver atoms have been removed for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  A perspective view of two layers of 2-D coordination polymer of 2 showing the packing of crystal and the location of the hexafluorophosphate anion sites in the crystal lattice. Layer A is shown blue and layer B colored green. Nitromethane solvate molecules, hydrogen atoms, and the disorder of the silver atoms have been removed for clarity.

cln_elements.content: (a) A perspective view of the packing of compound 2 showing the binding cavity in which the hexafluorophosphate anion is located. Radialene phenyl C−H···Fanion hydrogen bonds are shown as dashed lines. (b) A similar perspective view of the packing of compound 3 showing the disordered perchlorate anion in its hydrogen bonding donor pocket. Both disorder components of the perchlorate anion are shown; the chlorine atom of the dominant component is shown in yellow while the minor component is shown in cyan. Radialene phenyl C−H···Oanion hydrogen bonds are shown as dashed lines.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (a) A perspective view of the packing of compound 2 showing the binding cavity in which the hexafluorophosphate anion is located. Radialene phenyl C-H⋅⋅⋅Fanion hydrogen bonds are shown as dashed lines. (b) A similar perspective view of the packing of compound 3 showing the disordered perchlorate anion in its hydrogen bonding donor pocket. Both disorder components of the perchlorate anion are shown; the chlorine atom of the dominant component is shown in yellow while the minor component is shown in cyan. Radialene phenyl C-H⋅⋅⋅Oanion hydrogen bonds are shown as dashed lines.

metadata.title:
2-D Coordination Polymers of Hexa(4-cyanophenyl)[3]-radialene and Silver(I): Anion···π-Interactions and Radialene C−H···Anion Hydrogen Bonds in the Solid-State Interactions of Hexaaryl[3]-radialenes with Anions
Coordination Polymers of Hexa(4-cyanophenyl)[3]-radialene
